awd_titl_txt: Empowering Dementia Caregivers using a Culturally Relevant Cyber-Human System
awd_abstract_narration:
African Americans are more frequently diagnosed with dementia than other groups in the United States. Despite the prevalence, there is little research targeting technology use to enhance the functioning of African Americans living with dementia and their caregivers. This study utilizes a novel approach to develop a research model that advances cyber-human systems research on dementia caregiving in the African American community. The project uses a cultural foundation to explore the needs and preferences of users to drive the development of technological systems that can be readily adopted by the African American community. Moreover, this study will contribute to increasing awareness of culturally-sensitive research approaches to improve the understanding of the use of technology in dementia. Ultimately, this project will serve as the catalyst for future technological advances in culturally-relevant smart and connected health.

The overarching goal of this project is to develop a culturally-relevant cyber-human system than can improve the effectiveness of caregivers of people with dementia -- and subsequently other diverse populations -- by reducing caregiver burden. This cyber-human system modeling approach utilizes information from dementia agitation episodes, self-reported caregiver response (e.g., mood and perceived stress), as well as unique attributes of the African American community with dementia. These data are used in a cyber-human system to predict unbiased agitation models so that caregivers and can be primed with an optimal response that reduces their burden and supports the functioning of the person with dementia. The results of this study will enhance the use of cyber-human systems for family caregiving.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Compared to other racial and ethnic categories, African Americans are more likely to be diagnosed with dementia. Due to the lack of culturally-focused socio-technical research, the burden of this disease on African American is not well-understood. In this study, we conducted a survey to collect data from familial caregivers of persons with dementia to determine predictors and indicators of caregiver burden for African Americans as well as other groups.

We compiled a survey instrument consisting of demographic questionnaire and four well-established psychometric survey batteries, selected to assess the burden of caregivers of persons with dementia. The four batteries of the survey garnered information about PwD behavior (NPIQ), caregiver concerns (ZBI-12), caregiver health (SF20) and perceived social support from the caregiver's friends, family, and significant others (MSPSS). We recruited our survey participants (i.e., familial caregivers) with the help of Alzheimer's Association and other community organizations. Using the dataset collected from survey participants, we developed features (predictors of caregiver burden) and indicators (severity levels and types of burden). 

Our goal was to determine the sources and best indicators of caregiver burden. To achieve this goal, we developed mathematical and computational models using neural network-based machine learning methods. Finally, we compared our results for two racial ethnic population groups: African American and Caucasian.  Our main findings are as follows.

  • Both distress from neuropsychiatric behavior and the number of neuropsychiatric behaviors were strong indicators of burden for African American caregivers. However, only the number of neuropsychiatric behaviors (but not distress) was a suitable indicator of burden for the Caucasian caregiver.
  • African American caregiver burden was most accurately predicted using the frequency and severity of neuropsychiatric behavior as compared to using predictors from all four survey instruments. However, for Caucasian caregivers, frequency and severity of neuropsychiatric behavior resulted in considerably weaker accuracy values in its prediction of burden.
  • Prediction of burden using a combined dataset (i.e., data from all four psychometric survey batteries) proved to be suitable for African Americans; however, in all cases when predictors from this combined dataset was used, Caucasian caregiver burden failed to produce accurate results.

Overall, the determinants of caregiver burden differed between African American and Caucasian. Hence, it is important to utilize culturally-sensitive assessment tools and develop culturally-responsive interventions aimed at decreasing caregiver burden.

Intellectual Merit. Leveraging the expertise from computer science and social science fields, the research team addressed the need of understanding dementia caregiver burden across demographics, and thereby contributed to health equity. This study contributed to advanced knowledge of the contexts and requirements necessary to develop smart and connected sociotechnical systems for the analysis and reduction of caregiver burden. Furthermore, the culturally-centered computational models derived from this effort contributed to the knowledge domain in areas of fairness, ethics, accountability and transparency (FEAT). The collaboration between interdisciplinary researchers and the Alzheimer's community allowed creative integration of data and information yielding original concepts useful to the research community and potentially transformative for advances in technological equity. Moreover, our students have acquired a keen sense of cultural relevance as it relates to research. 

Broader Impact: This study contributed to the empowerment of familial caregivers of African American persons with dementia. The project activities and outcomes increased awareness of culturally sensitive issues and the impact of these unique aspects on African American caregivers. The result of this exploratory study is expected to engender further interest in improving cyber-human systems for familial caregiving. In broadening participation, we have engaged both master's and PhD-level graduate students from North Carolina A&T State University to develop their research and scholarship talent in STEM careers involving research on complex community health systems.
